sentence.text: Drug Label for drug brand Aceon, containing perindopril erbumine.

mmtx.phraseText: Drug Label for drug brand Aceon,
Drug Label for drug brand Aceon,

sentence.text: ACEON (perindopril erbumine) is contraindicated in patients known to be hypersensitive (including angioedema) to this product or to any other ACE inhibitor.
Do not co-administer aliskiren with ACEON in patients with diabetes see Drug Interactions (7.8).
<item>Do not co-administer aliskiren with ACEON in patients with diabetes (4.0, 7.8)

Presumably because angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors affect the metabolism of eicosanoids and polypeptides, including endogenous bradykinin, patients receiving ACE inhibitors (including ACEON) may be subject to a variety of adverse events, some of them serious.

Head and Neck Angioedema: Angioedema of the face, extremities, lips, tongue, glottis, or larynx has been reported in patients treated with ACE inhibitors, including ACEON (0.1% of patients treated with ACEON in U.S. clinical trials).
The angioedema was diagnosed by procedures including abdominal CT scan or ultrasound, or at surgery, and symptoms resolved after stopping the ACE inhibitor.
Patients should be followed closely for the first two weeks of treatment and whenever the dose of ACEON and/or diuretic is increased.
As a consequence of inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, changes in renal function may be anticipated in susceptible individuals.

In patients with severe congestive heart failure, where renal function may depend on the activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, treatment with ACE inhibitors, including ACEON, may be associated with oliguria, progressive azotemia, and, rarely, acute renal failure and death.

mmtx.phraseText: depend on the activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system,
depend on the activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system,

sentence.text: In hypertensive patients with unilateral or bilateral renal artery stenosis, increases in blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine may occur, usually reversible upon discontinuation of the ACE inhibitor.

mmtx.phraseText: usually reversible upon discontinuation of the ACE inhibitor.

sentence.text: Some ACEON-treated patients have developed minor and transient increases in blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine especially in those concomitantly treated with a diuretic.
Elevations of serum potassium have been observed in some patients treated with ACE inhibitors, including ACEON.

Risk factors for the development of hyperkalemia include renal insufficiency, diabetes mellitus and the concomitant use of agents such as potassium-sparing diuretics, potassium supplements and/or potassium-containing salt substitutes see Drug Interactions (7.2).

ellipsisSentence.text: Elevations of serum potassium have been observed in some patients treated with ACE inhibitors, including ACEON.

middleSentence.text: Most cases were isolated single values that did not appear clinically relevant and were rarely a cause for withdrawal.

sentence.text: Serum potassium should be monitored periodically in patients receiving ACEON.
In patients undergoing surgery or during anesthesia with agents that produce hypotension, ACEON may block angiotensin II formation that would otherwise occur secondary to compensatory renin release.
<item>Diuretics: Excessive drop in blood pressure (7.1)

ellipsisSentence.text: In patients undergoing surgery or during anesthesia with agents that produce hypotension, ACEON may block angiotensin II formation that would otherwise occur secondary to compensatory renin release.

middleSentence.text: Hypotension attributable to this mechanism can be corrected by volume expansion.

sentence.text: <item>Potassium-sparing diuretics/potassium supplements: Hyperkalemia (7.2)

ellipsisSentence.text: In patients undergoing surgery or during anesthesia with agents that produce hypotension, ACEON may block angiotensin II formation that would otherwise occur secondary to compensatory renin release.

middleSentence.text: Hypotension attributable to this mechanism can be corrected by volume expansion.

sentence.text: <item>Lithium: Increase serum lithium levels, symptoms of lithium toxicity (7.3)

ellipsisSentence.text: In patients undergoing surgery or during anesthesia with agents that produce hypotension, ACEON may block angiotensin II formation that would otherwise occur secondary to compensatory renin release.

middleSentence.text: Hypotension attributable to this mechanism can be corrected by volume expansion.

ellipsisSentence.text: In patients undergoing surgery or during anesthesia with agents that produce hypotension, ACEON may block angiotensin II formation that would otherwise occur secondary to compensatory renin release.

middleSentence.text: Hypotension attributable to this mechanism can be corrected by volume expansion.

sentence.text: <item>Injectable gold: Nitritoid reactions (facial flushing, nausea, vomiting, and hypotension) (7.4)
<item>NSAID use may lead to increased risk of renal impairment and loss of antihypertensive effect (7.7)

mmtx.phraseText: lead to increased risk of renal impairment
lead to increased risk of renal impairment

sentence.text: <item>Dual inhibition of the renin-angiotensin system: Increased risk of renal impairment, hypotension, and hyperkalemia (7.8).

entity.text: Dual inhibition of the renin-angiotensin system

sentence.text: Patients on diuretics, and especially those started recently, may occasionally experience an excessive reduction of blood pressure after initiation of ACEON therapy.
The possibility of hypotensive effects can be minimized by either decreasing the dose of or discontinuing the diuretic or increasing the salt intake prior to initiation of treatment with perindopril.

If diuretic therapy cannot be altered, provide close medical supervision with the first dose of ACEON, for at least two hours and until blood pressure has stabilized for another hour see Warnings and Precautions (5.2).

mmtx.phraseText: close medical supervision with the first dose of ACEON,

sentence.text: The rate and extent of perindopril absorption and elimination are not affected by concomitant diuretics.
The bioavailability of perindoprilat was reduced by diuretics, however, and this was associated with a decrease in plasma ACE inhibition.
7.2 Potassium Supplements and Potassium-Sparing Diuretics
ACEON may increase serum potassium because of its potential to decrease aldosterone production.

mmtx.phraseText: serum potassium because of its potential to

sentence.text: Use of potassium-sparing diuretics (spironolactone, amiloride, triamterene and others), potassium supplements or other drugs capable of increasing serum potassium (indomethacin, heparin, cyclosporine and others) can increase the risk of hyperkalemia.

entity.text: drugs capable of increasing serum potassium

ellipsisSentence.text: ACEON may increase serum potassium because of its potential to decrease aldosterone production.

sentence.text: Therefore, if concomitant use of such agents is indicated, monitor the patient's serum potassium frequently.

ellipsisSentence.text: Use of potassium-sparing diuretics (spironolactone, amiloride, triamterene and others), potassium supplements or other drugs capable of increasing serum potassium (indomethacin, heparin, cyclosporine and others) can increase the risk of hyperkalemia.
ACEON may increase serum potassium because of its potential to decrease aldosterone production.

middleSentence.text: Use of potassium-sparing diuretics (spironolactone, amiloride, triamterene and others), potassium supplements or other drugs capable of increasing serum potassium (indomethacin, heparin, cyclosporine and others) can increase the risk of hyperkalemia.

ellipsisSentence.text: Use of potassium-sparing diuretics (spironolactone, amiloride, triamterene and others), potassium supplements or other drugs capable of increasing serum potassium (indomethacin, heparin, cyclosporine and others) can increase the risk of hyperkalemia.

Use of potassium-sparing diuretics (spironolactone, amiloride, triamterene and others), potassium supplements or other drugs capable of increasing serum potassium (indomethacin, heparin, cyclosporine and others) can increase the risk of hyperkalemia.

sentence.text: Increased serum lithium and symptoms of lithium toxicity have been reported in patients receiving concomitant lithium and ACE inhibitor therapy.
Frequent monitoring of serum lithium concentration is recommended.

mmtx.phraseText: Frequent monitoring of serum lithium concentration

ellipsisSentence.text: Increased serum lithium and symptoms of lithium toxicity have been reported in patients receiving concomitant lithium and ACE inhibitor therapy.

sentence.text: Use of a diuretic may further increase the risk of lithium toxicity.

Nitritoid reactions (symptoms include facial flushing, nausea, vomiting and hypotension) have been reported rarely in patients on therapy with injectable gold (sodium aurothiomalate) and concomitant ACE Inhibitor therapy including ACEON.

A controlled pharmacokinetic study has shown no effect on plasma digoxin concentrations when coadministered with ACEON, but an effect of digoxin on the plasma concentration of perindopril/perindoprilat has not been excluded.

mmtx.phraseText: no effect on plasma digoxin concentrations

sentence.text: Animal data have suggested the possibility of interaction between perindopril and gentamicin.
7.7 Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Agents including Selective Cyclooxygenase-2 Inhibitors (COX-2 Inhibitors)

In patients who are elderly, volume-depleted (including those on diuretic therapy), or with compromised renal function, co-administration of NSAIDs, including selective COX-2 inhibitors, with ACE inhibitors, including perindopril, may result in deterioration of renal function, including possible acute renal failure.
Monitor renal function periodically in patients receiving perindopril and NSAID therapy.
The antihypertensive effect of ACE inhibitors, including perindopril, may be attenuated by NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors.

mmtx.phraseText: The antihypertensive effect of ACE inhibitors,

sentence.text: 7.8 Dual Blockade of the Renin-Angiotensin System (RAS)

mmtx.phraseText: 7.8 Dual Blockade of the Renin-Angiotensin System
7.8 Dual Blockade of the Renin-Angiotensin System

sentence.text: Dual blockade of the RAS with angiotensin receptor blockers, ACE inhibitors, or aliskiren is associated with increased risks of hypotension, hyperkalemia, and changes in renal function (including acute renal failure) compared to monotherapy.

ellipsisSentence.text: The antihypertensive effect of ACE inhibitors, including perindopril, may be attenuated by NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors.

middleSentence.text: 7.8 Dual Blockade of the Renin-Angiotensin System (RAS)

ellipsisSentence.text: The antihypertensive effect of ACE inhibitors, including perindopril, may be attenuated by NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors.

ellipsisSentence.text: The antihypertensive effect of ACE inhibitors, including perindopril, may be attenuated by NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors.

middleSentence.text: 7.8 Dual Blockade of the Renin-Angiotensin System (RAS)

ellipsisSentence.text: The antihypertensive effect of ACE inhibitors, including perindopril, may be attenuated by NSAIDs including selective COX-2 inhibitors.

middleSentence.text: 7.8 Dual Blockade of the Renin-Angiotensin System (RAS)

sentence.text: Closely monitor blood pressure, renal function and electrolytes in patients on ACEON and other agents that affect the RAS.
Do not co-administer aliskiren with ACEON in patients with diabetes.
Avoid use of aliskiren with ACEON in patients with renal impairment (GFR 60 ml/min).
